text: Hello and welcome everyone. I'm Corey Hofstein and this is Flirting with Models, the podcast that pulls back the curtain to discover the human factor behind the quantitative strategy. Corey Hofstein is the co-founder and chief investment officer of Newfound Research. Due to industry regulations, he will not discuss any of Newfound Research's funds on this podcast. All opinions expressed by podcast participants are solely their own opinion and do not reflect the opinion of Newfound Research. This podcast is for informational purposes only and should not be relied upon as a basis for investment decisions. Clients of Newfound Research may maintain positions and securities discussed in this podcast. For more information, visit thinknewfound.com. If you enjoyed this podcast, we'd greatly appreciate it if you could leave us a rating or review on your favorite podcast platform. And check out our sponsor. This season, well, it's me. People ask me all the time, Corey, what do you actually do? Well, back in the day, I was a journalist. Now I'm a journalist. in 2008, I co-founded Newfound Research. We're a quantitative investment and research firm dedicated to helping investors proactively navigate the risks of investing through more holistic diversification. Whether through the funds we manage, the exchange-traded products we power, or the total portfolio solutions we construct, like the Structural Alpha Model Portfolio Series, we offer a variety of solutions to financial advisors and institutions. Check us out at www.thinknewfound.com. And now on with the show. Today I'm joined by Hari Krishnan, Head of Volatility Strategies at SCT Capital and author of the books Second Leg Down and Market Tremors. We begin with the discussion of Hari's newest book, Market Tremors, and the main theoretical idea of mean field theory. Hari lays out both the philosophical underpinnings of the concept and the theoretical idea of mean field theory. As well as how one might interpret it in practice. This leads into a natural discussion of dominant agents, including examples of who they are, how one might go about identifying them, and why are they so important to consider. In the back half of the conversation, we tackle some more practical considerations of tail risk hedging. This includes key differences between equity and rates markets, how we might structure hedges in today's market environment, how to navigate path dependency, and why we might want to use them. So let's get started. Hari Krishnan, welcome to the podcast. Excited to get you on. Right before we started recording, I said never really want to talk about what date or time we're recording this because I like these to be evergreen. And yet I think I'm going to break my own rule right out of the gate. This is June 16th, 2022. And it's been an interesting week. Maybe it'll come up in the next few weeks. But it seems like a very timely day to be talking tail risk management, which is what we're going to be talking about on this episode. So thank you for joining me. It's a pleasure, Guri. I've followed you with interest for a long time. So I'm happy to be here. Well, before we dive into all things technical, let's maybe start at the beginning with your background, because I do know your path into tail risk management wasn't necessarily direct. And I'm a big believer that those formative years ultimately end up in the long run. So I'm going to start with you. So I'm going to start with you. So I'm going to start with you. So I'm going to start with you. So I'm going to start with you.
